SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of word relationships and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the line from the poem.
:box:As though they all were coached.
What does the line show about the sandpipers?

A.Choice: They seem to be getting stronger.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported in the context of the two stanzas focused on sandpipers.

B.Choice: They seem to be playing games with each other.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported in the context of the two stanzas focused on sandpipers.

C.Choice: It seems like someone is telling them what to do.

Key.Rationale: The word “coached” suggests that the sandpipers' quick movements are influenced by someone's directions.

D.Choice: It seems like someone is helping them learn something.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported in the context of the two stanzas focused on sandpipers.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of word relationships and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Which two words from the poem are most alike in meaning?

Key.Rationale: “Soft” and “gentle” are synonyms.
The words “walked” and “passed” are not synonyms because one can pass by others with movements other than walking.
Te words “moved” and “searched” are not synonyms.
While one can think that something that is “giant” is “awesome,” the words are not synonyms.

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Which animals in the poem leave the beach before the sun comes up?

Key.Rationale: No evidence in the poem suggests that these animals leave the beach.
The poem indicates that “The turtles then go back to sea, / Before the morning light.”
No evidence in the poem suggests that these animals leave the beach.
No evidence in the poem suggests that these animals leave the beach.

SubTopics: Recount poems, dramas, or stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: Which detail from the poem best tells what the poem is about?

A.Choice: “The sun was rising in the east.”

Key.Rationale: This choice merely provide examples of the speaker's observations of activities seen at the beach.
This choice merely provide examples of the speaker's observations of activities seen at the beach.
This choice merely provide examples of the speaker's observations of activities seen at the beach.

D.Choice: “The beach is such an awesome place,”

Key.Rationale: The poem is about all the ways that the beach is a special place.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Why do the pelicans “sit and wait and look”?

A.Choice: to see how the fishermen find fish

Key.Rationale: The phrase “dive and clean his hook” provides textual evidence that the pelicans steal the fish.

B.Choice: to show other birds how to get fish

Key.Rationale: This choice not supported at all in the text of the poem.

C.Choice: to take fish away from the fishermen

Key.Rationale: After a fisherman catches a fish, the pelican dives under the water to take his fish from the hook.

D.Choice: to scare other birds away from the fish

Key.Rationale: This choice not supported at all in the text of the poem.

Topics: Reading Literature - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain the point of view from which a story is narrated, including the difference between first- and third-person narrations.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
Which description best shows how the first person point of view is used in the poem?

A.Choice: through a speaker who shares facts about the beach

Key.Rationale: The speaker shares his/her observations, not facts about the beach.

B.Choice: through a speaker who shares a dream about the beach

Key.Rationale: There is no indication that the poem is a dream.

C.Choice: through a speaker who shares personal feelings about the beach

Key.Rationale: Such words as “lovely,” “magical,” “pretty,” and “awesome” indicate the speaker's feelings about the beach.

D.Choice: through a speaker who shares other people's feelings about the beach

Key.Rationale: The feelings expressed are those of the speaker, not of someone else.

Content: Which line from the poem best supports the answer in Part One? Choose one answer.

Key.Rationale: This choice reflects the speaker's observations, not feelings.
The word “lovely” shows the personal feelings of the speaker.
This choice reflects the speaker's observations, not feelings.
This choice reflects the speaker's observations, not feelings.

SubTopics: Recount poems, dramas, or stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: What lesson can be learned from the speaker of the poem? Use details from the poem to support your answer.
Read the sentence.
:box:The reader felt the character's when the character's team won the big game.
Which word best completes the sentence?

Key.Rationale: Although the character can be inferred to have power since he/she won the game, this option is not the best answer.
This choice is not supported by the context of the sentence.
Although the character may be brave for playing in a game, this option is not the best answer.
This abstract noun is best supported by the context.

SubTopics: Choose words and phrases for effect.
Content: Read the sentences from a story.
:box:(1) On a warm summer's day, Mark went with his family to pick strawberries. (2) He was given his very own box to fill. (3) In less than an hour, his box.
Choose the most descriptive group of words to complete sentence 3.

A.Choice: had more than enough strawberries in it

Key.Rationale: This choice is less specific and vivid.

B.Choice: had plenty of good strawberries in it

Key.Rationale: This choice is less specific and vivid.

C.Choice: was packed full of juicy strawberries

Key.Rationale: The words “packed full” and “juicy” provide the most imagery.

D.Choice: was all filled with wonderful strawberries

Key.Rationale: This choice is less specific and vivid.

SubTopics: Use commas and quotation marks in dialogue.
Content: Which sentence needs a comma and quotation marks?

A.Choice: Our teacher told us about our trip to the aquarium.

Key.Rationale: No quotation marks or commas are needed since the answers do not include dialogue.

B.Choice: He said that we would see fish of all different sizes.

Key.Rationale: No quotation marks or commas are needed since the answers do not include dialogue.

C.Choice: I was excited when he said we would also see turtles.

Key.Rationale: No quotation marks or commas are needed since the answers do not include dialogue.

D.Choice: I'm going to have fun at the aquarium I told my mom.

Key.Rationale: This choice includes dialogue. Quotation marks are needed starting before “I'm” and ending after “aquarium,” and a comma is needed after the word “aquarium.”

SubTopics: Form and use regular and irregular plural nouns.
Content: Read the sentences.
:box:Many different a͟n͟i͟m͟a͟l͟s live on or near my uncle's farm. There are p͟o͟n͟y͟s in the field. There are g͟e͟e͟s͟e near the water. There are even d͟e͟e͟r in the woods.
Which underlined word should be changed to correct the mistake?

Key.Rationale: This choice is correct in the given sentences.
The correct plural form of “pony” is “ponies,” not “ponys.”
This choice is correct in the given sentences.
This choice is correct in the given sentences.
